body:
Comment 3: 
Cygwin does not play nicely with the surrounding system.
It's whole reason to exist is to let Windows users believe
they are on a Unix system, and that's very hard to do well
and uniformly.  Bugs are inevitable.

We are committed to not using bash, nor any of cygwin,
on Windows. I rewrote the bash files in batch for exactly
that reason, and Brad is rewriting the test/run script in Go.
Trying to keep the Windows port of bash happy is
not worth the trouble.

What does uname print on Windows?  We should put
a check in all.bash to print an error and exit on Windows.
They should use all.bat.

Russ
